title.text: A Logical Basis for the D Combinator and Normal Form in CCG

abstractContent.text: The standard set of rules defined in Combina-tory Categorial Grammar (CCG) fails to provide satisfactory analyses fora number of syntactic structures found in natural languages.
These structures can be analyzed elegantly by augmenting CCG with a class of rules based on the combinator D (Curry and Feys, 1958).
We show two ways to derive the D rules: one based on unary composition and the other based on a logical characterization of CCG's rule base (Baldridge, 2002).
We also show how Eisner's (1996) normal form constraints follow from this logic, ensuring that the D rules do not lead to spurious ambiguities.

introductionContent.text: Combinatory Categorial Grammar) is a compositional, semantically transparent formalism that is both linguistically expressive and computationally tractable.
It has been used fora variety of tasks, such as wide-coverage parsing, sentence realization), learning semantic parsers, dialog systems (, grammar engineering, and modeling syntactic priming ().
A distinctive aspect of CCG is that it provides a very flexible notion of constituency.
This supports elegant analyses of several phenomena (e.g., coordination, long-distance extraction, and intonation) and allows incremental parsing with the competence grammar).
Here, we argue that even with its flexibility, CCG as standardly defined is not permissive enough for certain linguistic constructions and greater incrementality.
Following, we remedy this by adding a set of rules based on the D combinator of combinatory logic.

(1) x/(y/z) :f y/w : g ⇒ x/(w/z): λh.f We show that CCG augmented with this rule improves CCG's empirical coverage by allowing better analyses of modal verbs in English and causatives in Spanish, and certain coordinate constructions.
The D rules are well-behaved; we show this by deriving them both from unary composition and from the logic defined by.
Both perspectives on D ensure that the new rules are compatible with normal form constraints for controlling spurious ambiguity.
The logic also ensures that the new rules are subject to modalities consistent with those defined by.
Furthermore, we define a logic that produces Eisner's constraints as grammar internal theorems rather than parsing stipulations.
